Comment: Here is a just finished ladder game in the Fischer-Sozin variation of the Sicilian Najdorf.  I have only recently started playing 2...d6 in the Sicilian and as a result, my opponent takes me out of book by move 9.
I won't be annotating every move as I will assume most of you are familiar with the opening moves, however, we do reach the variation by a move order transposition.
More typical is 3. d4 or 3. Bb5+
More typical is 3. d4 or 3. Bb5+
More typical is 3. d4 or 3. Bb5+
Attacking the e-pawn and inviting the advance 4. e5, when 4...de; 5. Nxe5 e6 causes Black no problems.
Still postponing the advance of the d-pawn.
Here I opt to keep my Queen's knight flexible and commit to the Scheveningen setup rather than the ...e5 systems after the White knight lands on d4.
After this move we transpose into the main lines of the Fischer-Sozin.
According to my opening book, White has tried no less than 9 different moves here.  7. Bb3, 7. Be3 and 7. Bg5 are the more standard continuations.
According to my opening book, White has tried no less than 9 different moves here.  7. Bb3, 7. Be3 and 7. Bg5 are the more standard continuations.
According to my opening book, White has tried no less than 9 different moves here.  7. Bb3, 7. Be3 and 7. Bg5 are the more standard continuations.
According to my opening book, White has tried no less than 9 different moves here.  7. Bb3, 7. Be3 and 7. Bg5 are the more standard continuations.
Swatting the bishop and clearing a path for the light-squared bishop to come to b7.  This will weaken the e6-square and as we will see in a few moves, White can often sacrifice on this square.
The only strategically consistent move.
Preparing to castle.

I hadn't seen this move in any of my preparation.  Qf3, f4, a3, a4, and Be3 are all standard moves.  I decide to play as if the bishop had come to e3 and wait to see how white would continue his attacking scheme.
White's setup seems a little passive, so I decide to let him sacrifice on e6, as I will have the two bishops in an open position and an open f-file for the 1 pawn equivalent material investment.
White's setup seems a little passive, so I decide to let him sacrifice on e6, as I will have the two bishops in an open position and an open f-file for the 1 pawn equivalent material investment.
Allowing...
White gets 2 pawns and a rook for the two minors, but material isn't everything!!! Still the position should be balanced, but I might be a little optimistic.
I want to capture with the queen and leave the d7-square free for the knight to jump into c5.
I want to capture with the queen and leave the d7-square free for the knight to jump into c5.
I want to capture with the queen and leave the d7-square free for the knight to jump into c5.
I was anticipating this move or Qd3, with play against the weak d-pawn and, with a later a4, play against my queenside.
I was anticipating this move or Qd3, with play against the weak d-pawn and, with a later a4, play against my queenside.
I was anticipating this move or Qd3, with play against the weak d-pawn and, with a later a4, play against my queenside.
Keeping lines closed and kicking the knight away from its observation of d5.  The knight can't jump in right away due to 15...Nxd5; 16. ed Qf5 and Black's pieces are coming active.
15. Na2 a5; 16. c3 was another way to play actively for white.  Here the knight can come to f4, where it once again eyes d5.
Heading for c5.
